hints_html: What are the particular and homogeneous solutions?
hints_latex: What are the particular and homogeneous solutions?
hints_raw: What are the particular and homogeneous solutions?
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
Notice that the ODE

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}u'' + 6u' + 25u = 15 \cos(5t)\end{aligned}\]

has a nonzero right-hand side. We will begin by solving the homogeneous equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}u'' + 6u' + 25u = 0.\end{aligned}\]

By making the ansatz \(u = \exp(rt)\) we arrive at

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}r^2 + 6r + 25 = 0\end{aligned}\]

with roots \(r = -3 \pm 4 i\). Complex roots of the form \(a+ib\) lead to solutions of the form

\[\begin{aligned} &e^{at}\sin(bt)\\ &e^{at}\cos(bt).\end{aligned}\]

Therefore the homogeneous solution is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}u_h = C_1 e^{-3t} \sin(4t) + C_2 e^{-3t} \cos(4t).\end{aligned}\]

The right-hand side is sinusoidal with argument \(5t\). We need to think of which functions (and their derivatives) that could lead to this possible right-hand side. The only such possible functions are

\[\begin{aligned} \cos(5t)\\ \sin(5t)\end{aligned}\]

and so, we will find a particular solution of the form

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}u_p = A \sin(5t) + B \cos(5t).\end{aligned}\]

Taking this particular solution and plugging it in to the ODE, we have:

\[\begin{aligned} (-25 A \sin(5t) - 25 B \cos(5t)) + 6(5 A \cos(5t) - 5B \sin(5t)) + 25(A \sin(5t) + B \cos(5t)) &= 15 \cos(5t) \\ -30B \sin(5t) + 30A \cos(5t) &= 15 \cos(5t)\end{aligned}\]

In comparing the coefficients of \(\sin(5t)\) and \(\cos(5t)\), we find that

\[\begin{aligned} B &= 0\\ A &= 1/2.\end{aligned}\]

The general solution to the ODE will be \(u = u_h + u_p\), giving

\[\begin{aligned} u = \frac{1}{2} \sin(5t) + C_1 e^{-3t} \sin(4t) + C_2 e^{-3t} \cos(4t).\end{aligned}\]

The initial conditions tell us

\[\begin{aligned} u(0)&=1\\ u'(0)&=-\frac{11}{2}\end{aligned}\]

From this, we have,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}u(0) = C_2 = 1\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} u'(0) = \left.\left(\frac{5}{2} \cos(5t) - 3 C_1 e^{-3t} \sin(4t) + 4 C_1 e^{-3t} \cos(4t) - 3 C_2 e^{-3t} \cos(4t) - 4 C_2 e^{-3t} \sin(4t)\right)\right|_{t=0} = \frac{5}{2} + 4 C_1 - 3 = \frac{-11}{2}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we get that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}C_1 = -5/4.\end{aligned}\]

The solution is thus

\[\begin{aligned} u(t) = \frac{1}{2} \sin(5t) - \frac{5}{4} e^{-3t} \sin(4t) + e^{-3t} \cos(4t).\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Notice that the ODE

:<math>
\displaystyle{}u'' + 6u' + 25u = 15 \cos(5t)
</math>

has a nonzero right-hand side. We will begin by solving the homogeneous equation

:<math>
\displaystyle{}u'' + 6u' + 25u = 0.
</math>

By making the ansatz <math>u = \exp(rt)</math> we arrive at

:<math>
\displaystyle{}r^2 + 6r + 25 = 0
</math>

with roots <math>r = -3 \pm 4 i</math>. Complex roots of the form <math>a+ib</math> lead to solutions of the form

:<math>
\begin{align}
&e^{at}\sin(bt)\\
&e^{at}\cos(bt).
\end{align}
</math>

Therefore the homogeneous solution is

:<math>
\displaystyle{}u_h = C_1 e^{-3t} \sin(4t) + C_2 e^{-3t} \cos(4t).
</math>

The right-hand side is sinusoidal with argument <math>5t</math>.  We need to think of which functions (and their derivatives) that could lead to this possible right-hand side.  The only such possible functions are

:<math>
\begin{align}
\cos(5t)\\
\sin(5t)
\end{align}
</math>

and so, we will find a particular solution of the form

:<math>
\displaystyle{}u_p = A \sin(5t) + B \cos(5t).
</math>

Taking this particular solution and plugging it in to the ODE, we have:

:<math>
\begin{align}
(-25 A \sin(5t) - 25 B \cos(5t)) + 6(5 A \cos(5t) - 5B \sin(5t)) + 25(A \sin(5t) + B \cos(5t)) &= 15 \cos(5t)
\\ -30B \sin(5t) + 30A \cos(5t) &= 15 \cos(5t)
\end{align}
</math>

In comparing the coefficients of <math>\sin(5t)</math> and <math>\cos(5t)</math>, we find that 

:<math>
\begin{align}
B &= 0\\
A &= 1/2.
\end{align}
</math>

The general solution to the ODE will be <math>u = u_h + u_p</math>, giving

:<math>
u = \frac{1}{2} \sin(5t) + C_1 e^{-3t} \sin(4t) + C_2 e^{-3t} \cos(4t).
</math>

The initial conditions tell us

:<math>
\begin{align}
u(0)&=1\\
u'(0)&=-\frac{11}{2}
\end{align}
</math>

From this, we have, 

:<math>
\displaystyle{}u(0) = C_2 = 1
</math>

and 

:<math>
u'(0) = \left.\left(\frac{5}{2} \cos(5t) - 3 C_1 e^{-3t} \sin(4t) + 4 C_1 e^{-3t} \cos(4t) - 3 C_2 e^{-3t} \cos(4t) - 4 C_2 e^{-3t} \sin(4t)\right)\right|_{t=0} = \frac{5}{2} + 4 C_1 - 3 = \frac{-11}{2}.
</math>

Therefore we get that

:<math>
\displaystyle{}C_1 = -5/4.
</math>

The solution is thus

:<math>
u(t) = \frac{1}{2} \sin(5t) - \frac{5}{4} e^{-3t} \sin(4t) + e^{-3t} \cos(4t).
</math>
statement_html:
Suppose the motion of a spring-mass system is described by the following differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} 2u'' + 2\gamma u' + 18u = 0, \quad u(0) = 1, u'(0) = -\frac{11}2\end{aligned}\]

(b) Solve the following equation for u(t) in explicit form.

\[\begin{aligned} u'' + 6u' + 25u = 15\cos(5t), \quad u(0) = 1, u'(0) = -\frac{11}2\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Suppose the motion of a spring-mass system is described by the following differential equation

:<math>
2u'' + 2\gamma u' + 18u = 0, \quad u(0) = 1, u'(0) = -\frac{11}2
</math>

'''(b)''' Solve the following equation for ''u''(''t'') in explicit form.

:<math>
u'' + 6u' + 25u = 15\cos(5t), \quad u(0) = 1, u'(0) = -\frac{11}2
</math>
